name: Foreign Words That Have Crossed Over Quiz | Humanities | 10 Questions

questions.text: What does the German word, 'zeitgeist', mean?
questions.explanation:
Spirit of the time.

	'Spirit of the time' is a literal translation.

questions.text: Another German word that has 'crossed over' is 'weltschmerz'. What does it mean?
questions.correct: Sadness at the state of the world
questions.explanation:
Sadness at the state of the world.

	Sadness at comparing the real with the ideal.

questions.text: The French concept of 'savoir-faire' is commonly used. What does it mean?
Another popular French word is 'sang-froid'. Meaning?
questions.explanation:
Calm, imperturbable nature.

	One who always keeps his or her cool - regardless.

questions.text: The German language also speaks of 'weltanschauung'. What does it mean?
questions.explanation:
View of the world.

	Looking at the world today, of course, can be a bit depressing.

questions.text: Also German is the literary phrase, 'sturm und drang'. To what does it refer?
The French word, 'laissez-faire', is commonly used. What does it describe?
options: Socialization of essential aspects of society
questions.explanation:
No government interference.

	'Government is best which governs least'. Really?

questions.text: Hitler often spoke of 'lebensraum'. What does this word mean?
questions.explanation:
Living space.

	Austria's incorporation into the Third Reich was called 'Anschluss'.

questions.text: The French give us the word 'panache'. Meaning?
The French also speak of 'joie de vivre'. What does it mean?
questions.explanation:
Joy of Living.

	Literally, 'joy of living'.
